t: Mark 12
The Parable of the Vineyard Owner

He*p began to speak to them in parables: “A*r man*r planted*r a*r vineyard,*r put*r a*r fence*r around*r it,*r dug*r out*r a*r pit*r for*r a*r winepress,*r and*r built*r a*r watchtower.*r Then*r he*r leased*r it*r to*r tenant*r farmers*r and*r went*r away.*r
At*r harvest*r time*r he*r sent*r a*r servant*r to*r the*r farmers*r to*r collect*r some*r of*r the*r fruit*r of*r the*r vineyard*r from*r them.*r
But*r they*r took*r him,*r beat*r him,*r and*r sent*r him*r away*r empty-handed.*r
Again*r he*r sent*r another*r servant*r to*r them,*r and*r they*r hit*r him*r on*r the*r head*r and*r treated*r him*r shamefully.*r
Then*r he*r sent*r another,*r and*r they*r killed*r that*r one.*r He*r also*r sent*r many*r others;*r some*r they*r beat,*r and*r others*r they*r killed.*r
He*r still*r had*r one*r to*r send,*r a*r beloved*r son.*r Finally*r he*r sent*r him*r to*r them,*r saying,*r ‘They*r will*r respect*r my*r son.’*r
But*r those*r tenant*r farmers*r said*r to*r one*r another,*r ‘This*r is*r the*r heir.*r Come,*r let’s*r kill*r him,*r and*r the*r inheritance*r will*r be*r ours.’*r
So*r they*r seized*r him,*r killed*r him,*r and*r threw*r him*r out*r of*r the*r vineyard.*r
What*r then*r will*r the*r owner*r of*r the*r vineyard*r do?*r He*r will*r come*r and*r kill*r the*r farmers*r and*r give*r the*r vineyard*r to*r others.*r
Haven’t*r you*r read*r this*r Scripture:*r The*irpn stone*ir that*ir the*ir builders*ir rejected*ir has*irln become*ir the*ir cornerstone.*ir
This*irln came*ir about*ir from*ir the*ir Lord*ir and*irln is*ir wonderful*ir in*ir our*ir eyes?”*ir
They*p were looking for a way to arrest him but feared the crowd because they knew he had spoken this parable against them. So they left him and went away.
God and Caesar
Then*p they sent some of the Pharisees and the Herodians to Jesus to trap him in his words.

When they came, they said to him, “Teacher, we know you are truthful and don’t care what anyone thinks, nor do you show partiality but teach the way of God truthfully. Is it lawful to pay taxes to Caesar or not? Should we pay or shouldn’t we?”
But*p knowing their hypocrisy, he said to them, “Why*r are*r you*r testing*r me?*r Bring*r me*r a*r denarius*r to*r look*r at.”*r
They brought a coin. “Whose*r image*r and*r inscription*r is*r this?”*r he asked them. “Caesar’s,”*p they replied.
Jesus*p told them, “Give*r to*r Caesar*r the*r things*r that*r are*r Caesar’s,*r and*r to*r God*r the*r things*r that*r are*r God’s.”*r And they were utterly amazed at him.
The Sadducees and the Resurrection
Sadducees,*p who say there is no resurrection, came to him and questioned him:

“Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if*i a*i man’s*i brother*i dies,*i leaving a wife behind but no*i child,*i that*i man*i should*i take*i the*i wife*i and*i raise*i up*i offspring*i for*i his*i brother.*i
There were seven brothers. The first married a woman, and dying, left no offspring.
The second also took her, and he died, leaving no offspring. And the third likewise.
None of the seven left offspring. Last of all, the woman died too.
In the resurrection, when they rise, whose wife will she be, since the seven had married her?”
Jesus*p spoke to them, “Isn’t*r this*r the*r reason*r why*r you’re*r mistaken:*r you*r don’t*r know*r the*r Scriptures*r or*r the*r power*r of*r God?*r
For*r when*r they*r rise*r from*r the*r dead,*r they*r neither*r marry*r nor*r are*r given*r in*r marriage*r but*r are*r like*r angels*r in*r heaven.*r

And*r as*r for*r the*r dead*r being*r raised -*r haven’t*r you*r read*r in*r the*r book*r of*r Moses,*r in*r the*r passage*r about*r the*r burning*r bush,*r how*r God*r said*r to*r him:*r I*ir am*ir the*ir God*ir of*ir Abraham*ir and*ir the*ir God*ir of*ir Isaac*ir and*ir the*ir God*ir of*ir Jacob?*ir
He*r is*r not*r the*r God*r of*r the*r dead*r but*r of*r the*r living.*r You*r are*r badly*r mistaken.”*r
The Primary Commands
One*p of the scribes approached. When he heard them debating and saw that Jesus answered them well, he asked him, “Which command is the most important of all?”
Jesus*p answered, “The*r most*r important*r is*r Listen,*ir Israel!*ir The*ir Lord*ir our*ir God,*ir the*ir Lord*ir is*ir one.*ir
Love*ir the*ir Lord*ir your*ir God*ir with*ir all*ir your*ir heart,*ir with*ir all*ir your*ir soul,*ir with*ir all*ir your*ir mind,*ir and*ir with*ir all*ir your*ir strength.*ir
The*r second*r is,*r Love*ir your*ir neighbor*ir as*ir yourself.*ir There*r is*r no*r other*r command*r greater*r than*r these.”*r
Then*p the scribe said to him, “You are right, teacher. You have correctly said that he is one, and there is no one else except him.

And to love him with all your heart, with all your understanding, and with all your strength, and to love your neighbor as yourself, is far more important than all the burnt offerings and sacrifices.”
When*p Jesus saw that he answered wisely, he said to him, “You*r are*r not*r far*r from*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God.”*r And no one dared to question him any longer.
The Question about the Messiah
While*p Jesus was teaching in the temple, he asked, “How*r can*r the*r scribes*r say*r that*r the*r Messiah*r is*r the*r son*r of*r David?*r

David*r himself*r says*r by*r the*r Holy*r Spirit:*r The*irpn Lord*ir declared*ir to*ir my*ir Lord,*ir ‘Sit*irln at*ir my*ir right*ir hand*ir until*irln I*ir put*ir your*ir enemies*ir under*ir your*ir feet.’*ir
David*rp himself*r calls*r him*r ‘Lord.’*r How,*r then,*r can*r he*r be*r his*r son?”*r And the large crowd was listening to him with delight.
Warning against the Scribes
He*p also said in his teaching, “Beware*r of*r the*r scribes,*r who*r want*r to*r go*r around*r in*r long*r robes*r and*r who*r want*r greetings*r in*r the*r marketplaces,*r
the*r best*r seats*r in*r the*r synagogues,*r and*r the*r places*r of*r honor*r at*r banquets.*r
They*r devour*r widows’*r houses*r and*r say*r long*r prayers*r just*r for*r show.*r These*r will*r receive*r harsher*r judgment.”*r
The Widow’s Gift
Sitting*p across from the temple treasury, he watched how the crowd dropped money into the treasury. Many rich people were putting in large sums.
Then a poor widow came and dropped in two tiny coins worth very little.
Summoning his disciples, he said to them, “Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r this*r poor*r widow*r has*r put*r more*r into*r the*r treasury*r than*r all*r the*r others.*r
For*r they*r all*r gave*r out*r of*r their*r surplus,*r but*r she*r out*r of*r her*r poverty*r has*r put*r in*r everything*r she*r had*r — all*r she*r had*r to*r live*r on.”*r
